quote: Employ your time in improving yourself by other men’s writings so that you shall come easily by what others have labored hard for.
author: Unknown

quote: Well I am certainly wiser than this man. It is only too likely that neither of us has any knowledge to boast of; but he thinks that he knows something which he does not know, whereas I am quite conscious of my ignorance. At any rate it seems that I am wiser than he is to this small extent, that I do not think that I know what I do not know.
author: Unknown

quote: True wisdom comes to each of us when we realize how little we understand about life, ourselves, and the world around us.
author: Socrates

quote: The beginning of wisdom is a definition of terms.
author: Unknown

quote: What a lot of things there are a man can do without.
author: Unknown

quote: I cannot teach anybody anything. I can only make them think.
author: Unknown

quote: Slanderers do not hurt me because they do not hit me.
author: Unknown

quote: I was afraid that by observing objects with my eyes and trying to comprehend them with each of my other senses I might blind my soul altogether.
author: Unknown

quote: To find yourself, think for yourself.
author: Socrates

quote: Know thyself.
author: Unknown

quote: He who is not contented with what he has, would not be contented with what he would like to have.
author: Unknown

quote: If a man is proud of his wealth, he should not be praised until it is known how he employs it.
author: Unknown

quote: Where there is reverence there is fear, but there is not reverence everywhere that there is fear, because fear presumably has a wider extension than reverence.
author: Unknown

quote: They are not only idle who do nothing, but they are idle also who might be better employed.
author: Unknown

quote: One thing only I know, and that is that I know nothing.
author: Socrates

quote: Our prayers should be for blessings in general, for God knows best what is good for us.
author: Unknown

quote: I only wish that ordinary people had an unlimited capacity for doing harm; then they might have an unlimited power for doing good.
author: Unknown

quote: How many are the things I can do without!
author: Unknown

quote: I was really too honest a man to be a politician and live.
author: Unknown

quote: Ordinary people seem not to realize that those who really apply themselves in the right way to philosophy are directly and of their own accord preparing themselves for dying and death.
author: Unknown

quote: The hottest love has the coldest end.
author: Socrates

quote: See one promontory, one mountain, one sea, one river and see all.
author: Unknown

quote: A system of morality which is based on relative emotional values is a mere illusion, a thoroughly vulgar conception which has nothing sound in it and nothing true.
author: Unknown

quote: By all means marry. If you get a good wife you will become happy, and if you get a bad one you will become a philosopher.
author: Unknown

quote: When desire, having rejected reason and overpowered judgment which leads to right, is set in the direction of the pleasure which beauty can inspire, and when again under the influence of its kindred desires it is moved with violent motion towards the beauty of corporeal forms, it acquires a surname from this very violent motion, and is called love.
author: Unknown

quote: I pray Thee, O God, that I may be beautiful within.
author: Unknown

quote: The way to gain a good reputation is to endeavor to be what you desire to appear.
author: Socrates

quote: Nature has given us two ears, two eyes, and but one tongue-to the end that we should hear and see more than we speak.
author: Unknown

quote: In childhood be modest, in youth temperate, in adulthood just, and in old age prudent.
author: Unknown

quote: The end of life is to be like God, and the soul following God will be like Him.
author: Unknown

quote: We are in fact convinced that if we are ever to have pure knowledge of anything, we must get rid of the body and contemplate things by themselves with the soul by itself. It seems, to judge from the argument, that the wisdom which we desire and upon which we profess to have set our hearts will be attainable only when we are dead and not in our lifetime.
author: Unknown

quote: Nothing is to be preferred before justice.
author: Unknown

quote: Death may be the greatest of all human blessings.
author: Socrates

quote: Let him that would move the world, first move himself.
author: Unknown

quote: The comic and the tragic lie inseparably close, like light and shadow.
author: Unknown

quote: I am not an Athenian, nor a Greek, but a citizen of the world.
author: Unknown

quote: Call no man unhappy until he is married.
author: Unknown

quote: Happiness is unrepentant pleasure.
author: Unknown

quote: The unexamined life is not worth living.
author: Socrates

quote: Wars and revolutions and battles are due simply and solely to the body and its desires. All wars are undertaken for the acquisition of wealth; and the reason why we have to acquire wealth is the body, because we are slaves in its service.
author: Unknown

quote: No man undertakes a trade he has not learned, even the meanest; yet everyone thinks himself sufficiently qualified for the hardest of all trades, that of government.
author: Unknown

quote: The only good is knowledge and the only evil is ignorance.
author: Unknown

quote: The nearest way to glory is to strive to be what you wish to be thought to be.
author: Unknown

quote: Be slow to fall into friendship; but when thou art in, continue firm and constant.
author: Unknown

quote: Enjoy yourself — it’s later than you think.
author: Socrates

quote: Worthless people love only to eat and drink; people of worth eat and drink only to live.
author: Unknown

quote: Once made equal to man, woman becomes his superior.
author: Unknown

quote: Crito, I owe a cock to Asclepius; will you remember to pay the debt?
author: Unknown

quote: Fame is the perfume of heroic deeds.
author: Unknown

quote: The envious person grows lean with the fatness of their neighbor.
author: Unknown

quote: From the deepest desires often come the deadliest hate.
author: Socrates

quote: An education obtained with money is worse than no education at all.
author: Unknown

quote: Whom do I call educated? First, those who manage well the circumstances they encounter day by day. Next, those who are decent and honorable in their intercourse with all men, bearing easily and good naturedly what is offensive in others and being as agreeable and reasonable to their associates as is humanly possible to be… those who hold their pleasures always under control and are not ultimately overcome by their misfortunes… those who are not spoiled by their successes, who do not desert their true selves but hold their ground steadfastly as wise and sober — minded men.
author: Unknown

quote: False words are not only evil in themselves, but they infect the soul with evil.
author: Unknown

quote: The fewer our wants the more we resemble the Gods.
author: Unknown

quote: Life contains but two tragedies. One is not to get your heart’s desire; the other is to get it.
author: Unknown

quote: A multitude of books distracts the mind.
author: Socrates

quote: Whenever, therefore, people are deceived and form opinions wide of the truth, it is clear that the error has slid into their minds through the medium of certain resemblances to that truth.
author: Unknown

quote: If I tell you that I would be disobeying the god and on that account it is impossible for me to keep quiet, you won’t be persuaded by me, taking it that I am ionizing. And if I tell you that it is the greatest good for a human being to have discussions every day about virtue and the other things you hear me talking about, examining myself and others, and that the unexamined life is not livable for a human being, you will be even less persuaded.
author: Unknown

quote: The hour of departure has arrived and we go our ways; I to die, and you to live. Which is better? Only God knows.
author: Unknown

quote: To fear death, my friends, is only to think ourselves wise, without being wise: for it is to think that we know what we do not know. For anything that men can tell, death may be the greatest good that can happen to them: but they fear it as if they knew quite well that it was the greatest of evils. And what is this but that shameful ignorance of thinking that we know what we do not know?
author: Unknown

quote: Think not those faithful who praise all thy words and actions, but those who kindly reprove thy faults.
author: Unknown

quote: Contentment is natural wealth, luxury is artificial poverty.
author: Socrates

quote: Give me beauty in the inward soul; may the outward and the inward man be at one.
author: Unknown

quote: He is rich who is content with the least; for contentment is the wealth of nature.
author: Unknown

quote: Remember, no human condition is ever permanent. Then you will not be overjoyed in good fortune nor too scornful in misfortune.
author: Unknown

quote: Beauty is a short-lived tyranny.
author: Unknown

quote: The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.
author: Unknown

quote: There is only one good, knowledge, and one evil, ignorance.
author: Unknown

quote: Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.
author: Socrates

quote: Be kind, for everyone you meet is fighting a hard battle.
author: Unknown

quote: Every action has its pleasures and its price.
author: Unknown

quote: Remember what is unbecoming to do is also unbecoming to speak of.
author: Unknown

quote: Be as you wish to seem.
author: Unknown

quote: Do not do to others what angers you if done to you by others.
author: Unknown

quote: Beware the barrenness of a busy life.
author: Socrates

quote: Bad men live that they may eat and drink, whereas good men eat and drink that they may live.
author: Unknown

quote: I know that I am intelligent, because I know that I know nothing.
author: Unknown

quote: Are you not ashamed of heaping up the greatest amount of money and honor and reputation, and caring so little about wisdom and truth and the greatest improvement of the soul?
author: Unknown

quote: Remember that there is nothing stable in human affairs; therefore avoid undue elation in prosperity, or undue depression in adversity.
author: Unknown

quote: We cannot live better than in seeking to become better.
author: Unknown

quote: The secret of change is to focus all of your energy, not on fighting the old, but on building the new.
author: Socrates

quote: Smart people learn from everything and everyone, average people from their experiences, stupid people already have all the answers.
author: Unknown

quote: Education is the kindling of a flame, not the filling of a vessel.
author: Unknown

quote: The shortest and surest way to live with honour in the world, is to be in reality what we would appear to be; and if we observe, we shall find, that all human virtues increase and strengthen themselves by the practice of them.
author: Unknown

quote: No man has the right to be an amateur in the matter of physical training. It is a shame for a man to grow old without seeing the beauty and strength of which his body is capable.
author: Unknown

quote: I know nothing except the fact of my ignorance.
author: Unknown

quote: Silence is a profound melody, for those who can hear it above all the noise.
author: Socrates

quote: If you don’t get what you want, you suffer; if you get what you don’t want, you suffer; even when you get exactly what you want, you still suffer because you can’t hold on to it forever. Your mind is your predicament. It wants to be free of change. Free of pain, free of the obligations of life and death. But change is law and no amount of pretending will alter that reality.
author: Unknown

quote: There are two kinds of disease of the soul, vice and ignorance.
author: Unknown

quote: Sometimes you put walls up not to keep people out, but to see who cares enough to break them down.
author: Unknown

quote: Strong minds discuss ideas, average minds discuss events, weak minds discuss people.
author: Unknown

quote: The secret of happiness, you see, is not found in seeking more, but in developing the capacity to enjoy less.
author: Unknown

quote: When the debate is lost, slander becomes the tool of the loser.
author: Socrates

quote: Having the fewest wants, I am nearest to the gods.
author: Unknown

quote: The children now love luxury. They have bad manners, contempt for authority; they show disrespect for elders and love chatter in place of exercise.
author: Unknown

quote: Falling down is not a failure. Failure comes when you stay where you have fallen.
author: Unknown

quote: Prefer knowledge to wealth, for the one is transitory, the other perpetual.
author: Unknown

quote: Get not your friends by bare compliments, but by giving them sensible tokens of your love.
author: Unknown

quote: Be nicer than necessary to everyone you meet. Everyone is fighting some kind of battle.
author: Socrates

quote: All wars are fought for the acquisition of wealth.
author: Unknown

quote: Thou shouldst eat to live; not live to eat.
author: Unknown

quote: If you want to be a good saddler, saddle the worst horse; for if you can tame one, you can tame all.
author: Unknown

quote: One should never do wrong in return, nor mistreat any man, no matter how one has been mistreated by him.
author: Unknown

quote: Be the kind of person that you want people to think you are.
author: Unknown

quote: Understanding a question is half the answer.
author: Socrates

quote: The greatest way to live with honour in this world is to be what we pretend to be.
author: Unknown

quote: If all our misfortunes were laid in one common heap whence everyone must take an equal portion, most people would be content to take their own and depart.
author: Unknown

quote: We can easily forgive a child who is afraid of the dark; the real tragedy of life is when men are afraid of the light.
author: Unknown

quote: Children nowadays are tyrants. They contradict their parents, gobble their food, and tyrannise their teachers.
author: Unknown

quote: The greatest blessing granted to mankind come by way of madness, which is a divine gift.
author: Unknown

quote: There is no possession more valuable than a good and faithful friend.
author: Socrates

quote: The years wrinkle our skin, but lack of enthusiasm wrinkles our soul.
author: Unknown

quote: The highest realms of thought are impossible to reach without first attaining an understanding of compassion.
author: Unknown

quote: The easiest and noblest way is not to be crushing others, but to be improving yourselves.
author: Unknown

quote: When you want wisdom and insight as badly as you want to breathe, it is then you shall have it.
author: Unknown

quote: To move the world we must move ourselves.
author: Unknown

quote: Through your rags I see your vanity.
author: Unknown

quote: Envy is the ulcer of the soul.
author: Socrates
